figure_1.title: Figure 1. Post-operative radiograph of bilateral knees (anteroposterior view) .
figure_1.caption: Post-operative radiograph of bilateral knees in anteroposterior view with a broken drain in left knee marked with white arrows.

figure_2.title: Figure 2. Post-operative radiograph of the left knee (lateral view).
figure_2.caption: Post-operative radiograph of the left knee in lateral view delineating the broken drain piece with multiple black arrows.

figure_3.title: Figure 3. Per-operative image of the broken piece.

figure_4.title: Figure 4. A drainpipe of full length.
figure_4.caption: A drainpipe of full length showing the drain marker marked with a single black empty arrow along with suction holes in entirety marked with multiple black arrows.

figure_5.title: Figure 5. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “Are drains useful in knee arthroplasty surgery?”.

figure_6.title: Figure 6. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “Are there any recommendations by American association society of knee surgeons?”.

figure_7.title: Figure 7. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “The incidence of drain breakage during knee arthroplasty?” .

figure_8.title: Figure 8. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “How to secure a drain in knee arthroplasty?”.

figure_9.title: Figure 9. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “Drain technique in elective total joint arthroplasty by Sami Jaafar - is it an interesting read?”.

figure_10.title: Figure 10. Screenshot of OpenAI ChatGPT response to “How to handle a broken drain in an operated patient?” .

claims.sentence: The broken drain piece with a marker line was identified along the anterolateral aspect of the left knee radiograph in anteroposterior view (Figure 1) and a lateral view (Figure 2).
However, the studies that have found no significant difference in outcomes have been underpowered (Figure 5).
The American Association of Hip and Knee surgeon’s (AAHKS) has guidelines and recommendations on the use of drain in TKA (Figure 6).
Another study on 889 TKA reported a broken drain in two patients (0.2%) (Figure 7).
The drain can be secured in TKA with suture, staple, drain holder, adhesive strip, and tissue adhesive with emphasis on reducing the infection (Figure 8).
The drain requires monitoring and timely removal to minimize the complications [2] (Figure 9).
A prompt removal of drain is preferred based on the specific case and the patient overall health status (Figure 10).

We acknowledge the neutral opinion of OpenAI ChatGPT and have incorporated its suggestions in the final manuscript with relevant references.Appendices
Figure 5.
